questions.text: When falling on an outstretched hand, the most commonly dislocated carpal bone is the
questions.solution:
Explanation:

   Falling on an outstretched hand most commonly causes dislocation of the carpal bone - Lunate.

  • It is fairly common for the lunate to be dislocated anteriorly. This injury may result from a fall on an extended wrist.
  • The lunate may be pushed out of its place on the floor of the carpal tunnel and move toward the palm of the wrist.
  • This dislocation may compress the median nerve and lead to carpal tunnel syndrome.
  • Also remember: the scaphoid, the lateral bone in the proximal row of carpals, is frequently fractured when someone falls on an outstretched wrist
  • Capitate, hamate, and trapezoid are not commonly injured in these falls. (Option B, C and D ruled out)

Terry Thomas Sign:

  • Seen in scapholunate dissociation, often due to ligament rupture.
  • Appears as an abnormally widened gap between the scaphoid and lunate on an AP wrist X-ray.
  • Named after British comedian Terry-Thomas, known for the gap between his front teeth.

questions.text: If the musculocutaneous nerve is severed at its origin from the brachial plexus, flexion at the elbow is greatly weakened but not abolished. What muscle remains operative and can contribute to flexion?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Brachioradialis remains operative and can contribute to flexion if the musculocutaneous nerve is severed at its origin from the brachial plexus.

  • Brachioradialis is a muscle innervated by the radial nerve.
  • It flexes the elbow and assists in pronating and supinating the arm.
  • The musculocutaneous nerve (C5-C7) innervates:
    1. Biceps brachii (long and short heads)
    2. Brachialis
    3. Coracobrachialis
  • These are all the muscles that flex the arm and/or forearm
  • If this nerve is injured at its origin:
    1. Biceps and brachialis are paralysed
    2. Elbow flexion is weakened, but not abolished

questions.text: A 40-year-old man came to the ER after accidentally falling on the ice. It was found that a patient had a fracture as shown below. Care must be taken to relieve tension on the broken distal end of the radius created by the pull of which muscle?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given images suggest a Colles’ fracture. So, tension on the broken distal end of the radius is created by the pull of the Brachioradialis.

  • The Colles' fracture is a fracture to the distal end of the radius.
  • It usually occurs when someone tries to catch themselves from falling on an outstretched arm.
  • Tension is created by the muscle that inserts on the distal end of the radius.
  • Brachioradialis inserts on the lateral side of the base of the styloid process of the radius, so this muscle could pull the broken piece of the radius out of place.
  • This is why a cast over a Colles' fracture needs to extend up to the elbow, so that the brachioradialis can be immobilised.

Explanation for other options:

Extensor carpi ulnaris (Option A): It inserts on the medial side of the base of the 5th metacarpal.

Extensor carpi radialis longus (Option C): It inserts on the dorsum of the second metacarpal bone.

Pronator quadratus (Option D): It extends between the distal ulna and radius. It serves to pronate the hand. Although this muscle attaches to the broken part of the radius, it is not the most important muscle to stabilise following the injury.

  • Extensor carpi radialis brevis inserts on the dorsum of the third metacarpal bone.
  • So, none of the other muscles would pull on the distal piece of the radius as much as the brachioradialis.

choices.text: Flexion of the MP and IP joints of the thumb
Flexion of the proximal IP joints of digits 2 and 5
Flexion of the proximal IP joints of digits 3 and 4

questions.text: If the given tendon were transected, what movement would be affected?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given image shows the palmaris longus tendon. If it were transected, the movement of wrist flexion would be affected.

  • Palmaris longus is a small muscle in the anterior compartment of the arm: it flexes the hand at the wrist and tightens the palmar aponeurosis.
  • If this tendon were cut, it would be more difficult to flex the wrist.

Explanation for other options:

  • Flexor pollicis longus flexes the MP and IP joints of the thumb. (Option A ruled out)
  • Flexor digitorum profundus and superficialis flex the proximal IP joints of digits 2, 3, 4 and 5. (Option B and C ruled out)
  • Extensor carpi ulnaris, extensor carpi radialis longus and extensor carpi radialis brevis all extend the wrist.

questions.text: Which marked muscle is supplied by both the median and ulnar nerves?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  The C-marked muscle is the flexor digitorum profundus, which is supplied by both the median and ulnar nerves.

  • The radial half of flexor digitorum profundus is supplied by the median nerve, while the ulnar half of flexor digitorum profundus is supplied by the ulnar nerve.
  • The ulnar nerve also supplies the flexor carpi ulnaris in the anterior forearm.
  • The ulnar nerve is the 1 1/2 nerve; it supplies 1 1/2 muscles in the anterior forearm, and it supplies cutaneous innervation to 1 1/2 fingers on the ulnar side of the hand.
  • Composite muscles show the functional overlap between different nerves.
  • Important in localising nerve injuries: e.g., an ulnar nerve injury may weaken only half of the flexor digitorum profundus.

Explanation for other options:

A-Pronator quadratus (Option B)

B-Brachioradialis (Option D)

D-Flexor digitorum superficialis cut tendons (Option C)

  • Flexor digitorum superficialis, flexor pollicis longus, and pronator quadratus are innervated by the median nerve.
  • Brachioradialis is innervated by the radial nerve.

questions.text: The pulse of the radial artery at the wrist is felt immediately lateral to which tendon?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The pulse of the radial artery at the wrist is felt immediately lateral to the tendon of the flexor carpi radialis.

  • The radial artery runs on the radial side of the wrist, lateral to the tendon of the flexor carpi radialis.
  • The radial artery enters the wrist on the anterior side.
  • The tendons for flexor digitorum profundus and superficialis are found more towards the centre of the wrist, not on the lateral side. These tendons cross under the flexor retinaculum to reach the hand.

Explanation for other options:

A-Pronator teres (Option D): Located proximally in the forearm, not near the wrist

B-Palmaris longus (Option A): Tendon lies medial to FCR

D-Flexor carpi ulnaris (Option B): Located on the ulnar side of the wrist

questions.text: If the medial epicondyle of the humerus is fractured and the nerve passing dorsal to it is injured, which muscle would be most affected?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The nerve passing dorsal to the medial epicondyle of the humerus is the ulnar nerve; it innervates the flexor carpi ulnaris and the ulnar side of the flexor digitorum profundus. So, the flexor carpi ulnaris would be most affected if the ulnar nerve were disrupted.

  • Paralysis of hand muscles (except for the thenar compartment and the first two lumbricals) and numbness over the ulnar 1-5 digits in the hand were also noted.

Explanation for other options:

The extensor muscles (extensor digitorum and extensor carpi ulnaris) are in the posterior compartment of the forearm, and they are innervated by the radial nerve. (Option A and B ruled out)

Flexor digitorum superficialis is innervated by the median nerve only.

Although the ulnar side of flexor digitorum profundus would be impaired following the injury, the radial side of flexor digitorum profundus would still be innervated by the median nerve, which would be less affected than FCU. (Option D)

choices.text: Motor to the extensors of the forearm
Sensory from the dorsum of the hand

questions.text: After suffering a gunshot wound to the forearm, it was determined that the posterior interosseous nerve was severed. What function was lost?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The posterior interosseous nerve is the deep motor branch of the radial nerve. Its injury will cause damage to the motor function of the extensors of the forearm.

  • The posterior interosseous nerve passes through the supinator muscle and innervates all the extensor muscles of the forearm (except brachioradialis and extensor carpi radialis longus, which are supplied by the radial nerve before it splits).

Functions lost with the posterior interosseous nerve injury:

  • Extension of the wrist and fingers
  • Thumb extension and abduction
  • Results in finger drop and radial deviation due to unopposed flexors

Explanation for other options:

Sensory from the wrist joint (Option A): Posterior interosseous nerve gives some sensory innervation to the interosseous membrane and wrist joint, but loss is minimal and clinically insignificant

Motor to brachioradialis (Option B): Brachioradialis is innervated by the radial nerve before it branches into superficial and deep branches. So, it is intact.

Sensory from the dorsum of the hand (Option D): This is carried by the superficial branch of the radial nerve, not the posterior interosseous nerve.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man suffers a midshaft humeral fracture resulting in radial nerve injury. On examination, he has wrist drop and weakened supination of the forearm. However, supination is not completely lost, due to the preservation of a powerful supinator that is not innervated by the radial nerve. Which of the following muscles remains intact and continues to perform supination?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Biceps brachii is innervated by the musculocutaneous nerve, which also supinates the arm. So, it would not be affected by a radial nerve injury.

  • Brachialis is also innervated by the musculocutaneous nerve, but it is only involved with flexing the forearm; it is not a supinator. (Option A)
  • The brachioradialis flexes the elbow and assists in pronation and supination. It is innervated by the radial nerve and would be paralysed after a radial nerve injury. (Option C)
  • Flexor carpi radialis is a flexor, not a supinator; it is innervated by the median nerve. (Option D)
  • The supinator is innervated by the deep radial nerve

choices.text: Lateral supracondylar ridge of the humerus

questions.text: A worker doing repetitive lifting develops an inflammation in the tendon of origin of the extensor carpi radialis brevis muscle, commonly called "tennis elbow". The focal point of pain would most likely be near which palpable bony landmark?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The extensor carpi radialis brevis muscle originates from the common extensor tendon off the lateral epicondyle of the humerus. So, an injury to this tendon would result in pain near the lateral epicondyle.

  • Tennis elbow is due to the repetitive use of the superficial extensor muscles of the forearm. The pain is often felt at the lateral epicondyle, and it radiates down the posterior surface of the forearm.

choices.text: Flexion of the MP and IP joints of the thumb
Flexion of the PIP joints of digits 2 and 3
Flexion of the PIP joints of digits 3 and 4
Flexion of the DIP joints of digits 2 and 5

questions.text: In an attempt to commit suicide by slashing the ventral side of the wrist, the two tendons of the flexor digitorum superficialis, located most superficially, were completely severed. What movement would be affected?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

When cutting the ventral side of the wrist, the two tendons of the flexor digitorum superficialis, located most superficially, that would have been completely severed are the tendons that go to fingers 3 and 4, impairing flexion of the proximal interphalangeal joints of digits 3 and 4.

  • Flexor digitorum profundus (which has deeper tendons) is responsible for flexing the distal interphalangeal joints.
  • The tendons of flexor digitorum superficialis are arra nged in a packet with two superficial tendons and two deeper tendons. The tendons that go to fingers 3 and 4 are superficial, while the ones to fingers 2 and 5 are underneath.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman comes to you complaining of pain on the lateral side of her right elbow, so severe that she holds her eating utensils in her left hand to eat. She says that she spent the weekend putting in a new garden plot and that it involved loosening and turning over a large area of grass sods with a garden fork. You find that the region just proximal to the lateral epicondyle of her humerus is painful to the touch. There is no sensory loss in her forearm or hand. You suspect a localised tearing of the origin of a muscle producing the equivalent of the condition shown below. The muscle most likely involved is the:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Brachioradialis originates from the upper two-thirds of the lateral supracondylar ridge of the humerus, so this is the muscle that she probably tore in this scenario.

  • Tennis elbow is usually caused by inflammation of the common extensor tendon on the lateral side of the forearm, but here the tenderness is seen more proximally.
  • Brachioradialis flexes the elbow and assists in pronation and supination, so she would have been using this muscle while gardening.
  • The common flexor tendon is associated with the medial epicondyle, not the lateral epicondyle. (Option B)
  • Extensor carpi radialis brevis and extensor digitorum take origin from the common extensor tendon, which attaches to the lateral epicondyle. This tendon would be inflamed in a classic case of tennis elbow, but the common extensor tendon is not the structure that was injured in this patient's case. (Option C and D)
  • Pronator teres originates from the common flexor tendon and the medial side of the ulna.

questions.text: While going up for a rebound, a basketball player jams her middle finger against the ball. She experiences severe pain, and the trainer notes that she can no longer extend the distal phalanx of the finger. The injury has avulsed (torn away from the bone) the structure from her distal phalanx to produce this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Extensor expansion is the structure from her distal phalanx that has avulsed in this scenario.

  • Extensor expansions are widened ends of extensor tendons wrapping around metacarpal heads and proximal phalanges.
  • They insert on the bases of the middle and distal phalanges.
  • They hold the extensor tendon centrally on the digit and serve as attachment sites for lumbricals and interossei.
  • Tearing the extensor expansion disrupts tendon position and detaches the lumbricals, impairing joint extension.

Explanation for other options:

Extensor carpi radialis brevis and longus extend the wrist and abduct the hand, not involved in finger extension. (Option A and B ruled out)

Extensor digiti minimi and extensor indicis assist in extension of the 5th and 2nd fingers, respectively, not the 3rd finger. (Option C ruled out)

choices.text: The brachial artery lies medial to the median nerve in the cubital fossa
The posterior interosseous nerve passes between the two layers of the supinator
The ring finger's nerve supply is split between the radial and ulnar nerves.
The radial artery supplies the medial side of the hand and digits.

questions.text: Mark the correct statement.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The posterior interosseous nerve, also known as the dorsal interosseous nerve, is the continuation of the deep branch of the radial nerve after it penetrates the supinator muscle.

  • It carries fibres from the C7 and C8 spinal nerves and supplies the majority of the muscles in the posterior compartment of the forearm.

Explanation for other options:

In the cubital fossa, the median nerve lies medial to the brachial artery, not the other way around. [Mnemonic (lateral to medial): TAN - Tendon (biceps), Artery (brachial), Nerve (median)] (Option A ruled out)

The ring finger's nerve supply is split between the median and ulnar nerves. (Option C ruled out)

The radial artery primarily supplies blood to the forearm, wrist, and hand, particularly the lateral (thumb side) of the hand and three digits. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following muscles marked is wrong?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • 1 = Pronator Teres
  • 2 = Brachioradialis (Biceps Brachii is the wrong option)
  • 3 = Extensor Carpi Radialis Longus
  • 4 = Flexor Carpi Radialis Longus

The cubital fossa is a triangular depression on the anterior (front) side of the elbow.

Boundaries:

  • Lateral: Brachioradialis
  • Medial: Pronator teres
  • Superior (Base): Imaginary line between medial and lateral epicondyles
  • Apex: Intersection of brachioradialis and pronator teres
  • Roof: Skin, superficial fascia (with cephalic, basilic veins, median cubital vein), bicipital aponeurosis
  • Floor: Brachialis (medially) and supinator (laterally)

Contents (Lateral to Medial - TAN):

  • T - Tendon of biceps brachii
  • A - Brachial artery (and its bifurcation into radial & ulnar arteries)
  • N - Median nerve
  • Radial nerve (deep to brachioradialis, lateral to the fossa): divides into superficial and deep branches

choices.text: 1, 2, and 6 are known as the outcropping muscles of the deep extensor compartment of the forearm.
1 and 2 form the lateral boundary of the anatomical snuff box, while 6 forms the medial boundary.
6 passes through the 1st extensor compartment along with 1 and 2 under the extensor retinaculum.
2 inserts into the base of the proximal phalanx of the thumb.

questions.text: What is not true about the muscles marked 1, 2 and 6?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The three muscles acting on the thumb (1, 2 and 6) are Abductor pollicis longus, Extensor pollicis brevis, and Extensor pollicis longus, respectively.

  • Abductor pollicis longus(1) and Extensor pollicis brevis(2) pass through the 1st extensor compartment,
  • Extensor pollicis longus(6) passes through the 3rd extensor compartment

So, Option C is incorrect.

  • Abductor pollicis longus, Extensor pollicis brevis, and Extensor pollicis longus lie deep to the superficial extensors and emerge ("crop out") from a furrow in the lateral part of the forearm that divides the extensors. Because of this characteristic, they are referred to as outcropping muscles. (Option A ruled out)
  • Extensor pollicis brevis inserts into the base of the proximal phalanx, and the Extensor pollicis longus inserts into the base of the distal phalanx. (Option D ruled out)

Anatomical snuff box

The anatomical snuffbox is a triangular depression on the back of the hand, at the base of the thumb.

Boundaries:

  • Lateral: Tendons of the abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis muscles.
  • Medial: Tendon of the extensor pollicis longus muscle. (Option B ruled out)
  • Proximal (towards the wrist): Styloid process of the radius bone.
  • Floor: Scaphoid and trapezium bones.

Contents:

Radial artery, superficial branch of the radial nerve, and cephalic vein.

questions.text: Which of the following is not one of the rotator cuff muscles?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The deltoid muscle is not one of the rotator cuff muscles.

The Rotator cuff muscles

  • In rotator cuff muscles, the subscapularis, which was once considered the "forgotten tendon" due to a tendency to be overlooked in diagnoses and treatment.
  • It's the largest of the rotator cuff muscles,
  • Tears of the subscapularis were often missed or misdiagnosed as "hidden lesions," particularly in open repair surgeries,
  • Improved imaging techniques and surgical approaches have led to increased awareness and diagnosis of subscapularis tears.

The term "forgotten muscle" often refers to the serratus anterior, which plays a crucial role in shoulder blade movement and is frequently overlooked in shoulder exercises.

choices.text: A- Axillary nerve, B- Lateral epicondyle of humerus
A- Axillary nerve, B- Surgical neck of humerus
A- Radial nerve, B- Deltoid tuberosity of humerus
A- Axillary nerve, B- Anatomical neck of humerus

questions.text: During a Little League game, one of the players accidentally struck her teammate with her bat. When the bat hit the boy's arm, there was an audible crack, and the boy fell to the ground in pain. Luckily, one of the mothers watching was a physician, and she rushed to the boy's aid. Quick examination showed her that the boy had a closed fracture in his upper arm. After watching him abduct and rotate the arm, she diagnosed damage to the ___A____Damage to this nerve normally occurs when injury is located at the:____B____?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

After examination diagnosis of damage to the Axillary nerve was made.

Damage to the axillary nerve normally occurs when injury is located at the Surgical neck of the humerus.

  • The axillary nerve innervates the deltoid and teres minor, crucial for abduction and external rotation of the shoulder.
  • It passes around the surgical neck of the humerus with the posterior circumflex humeral artery.

Fracture at the surgical neck commonly injures this nerve, leading to:

  • Weakness in shoulder abduction (especially 15-90°)
  • Loss of sensation over the "regimental badge" area

Axillary Nerve

Motor Supply:

  • Anterior branch: Anterior deltoid
  • Posterior branch: Posterior deltoid, teres minor

Sensory Supply:

  • Upper lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm (from the posterior branch): skin over the inferior deltoid

Articular Supply:

  • Articular branch: Glenohumeral joint

Muscles Involved in Shoulder Abduction:

choices.text: Axillary nerve and Posterior circumflex humeral artery
Axillary nerve and Anterior circumflex humeral artery

questions.text: What is the content of the marked area?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Quadrangular space is the marked area that contains the axillary nerve and the posterior circumflex humeral artery.

  • The quadrangular space is a gap in the muscles of the posterior scapular region.
  • It is a pathway for neurovascular structures to move from the axilla anteriorly to the posterior shoulder and arm.
  • Boundaries
    1. Superior - inferior aspect of the teres minor
    2. Inferior-superior aspect of the teres major
    3. Lateral - surgical neck of the humerus.
    4. Medial - long head of triceps brachii
    5. Anterior - subscapularis
  • The axillary nerve, and posterior circumflex humeral artery and the vein pass through the quadrangular space.
  • These structures can be compressed as a result of trauma, muscle hypertrophy or space-occupying lesion, resulting in weakness of the deltoid and teres minor.

questions.text: To check the pulse of a child whose forearm is in a cast, the paediatrician presses her finger into the depth of the "anatomical snuffbox". The tendon lying immediately medial (ulnar) to the physician's finger belongs to what muscle?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The anatomical snuff box is bounded on the ulnar side by the tendon of extensor pollicis longus. So, on pressing the finger into the depth of the "anatomical snuffbox", the tendon lying immediately medial (ulnar) to the finger is the extensor pollicis longus tendon.

  • It is bounded radially by the tendons of abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis.
  • The radial artery lies in the floor of the anatomical snuff box, and the scaphoid can be felt in the floor of the anatomical snuff box.
  • Extensor carpi radialis longus and brevis attach their tendons to the base of the second and third metacarpals, respectively.
  • The brachioradialis inserts its tendon on the lateral side of the base of the styloid process of the radius.

questions.text: A patient presents with scapular winging visible at rest, without active arm movement. Physical examination shows the medial border of the scapula is displaced laterally and inferiorly (as shown in the image), but there is no prominence during forward arm flexion. Which nerve is most likely injured?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Scapular winging visible at rest, with no prominence during forward arm flexion, is caused by the dorsal scapular nerve injury.

Dorsal Scapular Nerve (C5)

  • The dorsal scapular nerve arises from the C5 root of the brachial plexus and innervates the rhomboid major, rhomboid minor, and levator scapulae
  • These muscles function primarily to retract (adduct) and elevate the scapula.
  • When this nerve is injured, the rhomboids become weak or paralysed, resulting in the medial border of the scapula drifting laterally.
  • This causes winging of the scapula at rest, without the need for active movement.
  • The patient may experience difficulty retracting the scapula.

Explanation for other options:

Long Thoracic Nerve (C5-C7) (Option A):

  • The long thoracic nerve innervates the serratus anterior muscle, which holds the scapula tightly against the thoracic wall during upper limb movements, particularly flexion and overhead reaching.
  • Injury to this nerve causes the classic form of scapular winging, characterised by the medial border of the scapula protruding posteriorly when the patient attempts to push against resistance.

Spinal Accessory Nerve (Cranial Nerve XI) (Option C):

  • The spinal accessory nerve supplies the trapezius muscle, which plays a crucial role in elevating the shoulder and rotating the scapula during arm abduction above 90 degrees.
  • Damage to this nerve results in shoulder drooping, difficulty elevating the arm, and, in some cases, mild winging of the scapula.
  • The winging tends to be secondary and is more noticeable during shoulder movement, not typically at rest.

Axillary Nerve (C5-C6) (Option D):

  • The axillary nerve innervates the deltoid and teres minor muscles, both of which are involved in shoulder abduction and external rotation, respectively.
  • Injury to this nerve impairs abduction beyond the first 15 degrees (initiated by the supraspinatus), but it does not affect scapular position or stability.

questions.text: A student is rollerblading on the road and, while trying to avoid a bicyclist, falls heavily on his right wrist. After the fall, he notes severe pain in the anatomical snuff box. Radiological studies reveal a fracture of the bone deep to the snuff box, which is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The scaphoid is the bone found at the floor of the anatomical snuff box. From the given X-ray findings, the fractured bone is the Scaphoid.

  • It is in the proximal row of carpals and is frequently fractured.
  • High risk of avascular necrosis due to poor blood supply.
  • The scaphoid and trapezium are the carpal bones that make up the floor of the anatomical snuffbox.
  • Borders of the ASB:
    • Radial border: Formed by the tendons of the abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis.
    • Ulnar border: Formed by the tendon of the extensor pollicis longus.
    • Apex (distal end): Points towards the first metacarpophalangeal joint.

Explanation for other options:

Capitate, hamate and trapezium are three carpal bones located in the distal row of carpals.

Capitate is the largest carpal bone; it transmits force from the hand to the lunate and the radius. Fractures are rare and typically occur with severe trauma. (Option A ruled out)

Hamate has a distinct hook; it is an attachment point for the flexor retinaculum.

Trapezium is the carpal bone that articulates with the metacarpal bone of the thumb, forming a saddle joint. Though it forms part of the floor of the snuff box, the scaphoid lies more centrally and deeper. Trapezium fractures are less common and usually involve thumb trauma, not a fall on an outstretched hand. (Option D ruled out)

The lunate is in the proximal row of carpal bones, located next to the scaphoid, and it articulates with the capitate. Commonly involved in dislocations, not isolated fractures, with snuff box tenderness. (Option B ruled out)

questions.text: In a patient with Erb-Duchenne palsy, nerves arising from the superior trunk of the brachial plexus are affected. Which of the following nerves will not be affected?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The medial pectoral nerve arises from the medial cord (C8-T1), not the superior trunk or C5 and C6 roots and will not be affected in Erb-Duchenne palsy

  • Erb-Duchenne palsy is the avulsion of the C5 and C6 roots of the brachial plexus.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding palsy shown below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The condition shown in the image is known as Erb's palsy or waiter's tip hand, which involves the forearm in pronation due to loss of supination (biceps paralysed) and intact pronators.

  • The wrist is flexed due to unopposed wrist flexors and gravity in Erb's palsy. (Option C)

questions.text: Identify the marked muscle.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hypothenar Muscles

questions.text: The marked muscle is innervated by
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The marked muscle is the abductor pollicis longus, which lies within the deep compartment of the posterior forearm.

  • The posterior interosseous branch of the radial nerve innervates the abductor pollicis longus muscle.

The tendon of the abductor pollicis longus passes through the 1st extensor compartment at the wrist, where it contributes to the radial border of the anatomical snuffbox.

  • Attachments: Originates from the interosseous membrane and the adjacent posterior surfaces of the radius and ulna. It attaches to the lateral aspect of the base of the first metacarpal.
  • Actions: Abduction of the thumb.
  • Blood supply: Ulnar artery.

questions.text: Which of the following has got nerve supply from all three nerves - ulnar nerve, median nerve and radial nerve?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The thumb receives contributions from all three major nerves of the upper limb.

Explanation for other options:

Ring finger (Option A): Median (lateral part) and ulnar (medial part) only,

Index finger (Option B): Median nerve for both motor and sensory; no ulnar or radial motor supply

Little finger (Option C): Ulnar nerve only (motor and sensory)

choices.text: The Card Test is used to assess the palmar interossei
The Wartenberg sign indicates an abducted little finger due to ulnar nerve palsy.
The Igawa test is used to evaluate the palmar interossei.
The Froment sign assesses the Adductor pollicis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding tests for intrinsic hand muscles?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Igawa test is not used for the evaluation of the palmar interossei.

  • The middle finger has only dorsal interossei and can move the middle finger to either side.
  • It specifically assesses the ability of the middle finger to abduct.
  • A positive Igawa test, where the patient cannot move the middle finger sideways, suggests an ulnar nerve injury.

Explanation for other options:

The card test (Option A): It evaluates the palmar interossei, which are responsible for the adduction of fingers. A card is placed between the patient's fingers, and they are asked to hold it. Inability to hold the card indicates ulnar nerve injury.

The Wartenberg sign (Option B): It is the passive abduction of the little finger due to weakness of the palmar interossei and lumbricals, with unopposed action of the extensor digiti minimi. It is a sign of ulnar nerve palsy.

The Froment sign test (Option D): The patient holds a piece of paper between the thumb and index finger; if the thumb flexes at the IP joint (using flexor pollicis longus, median nerve), it indicates ulnar nerve dysfunction affecting the adductor pollicis.

questions.text: Match the following signs with the respective nerve Injuries:

choices.text: Clawing is most pronounced in median nerve injury at the wrist
The deformity is due to paralysis of the thenar muscles

questions.text: What is the true statement about the given condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Flexion of the interphalangeal joint is the true statement in this condition.

This classic hand posture is due to ulnar nerve injury, most often at the wrist level. (Option C)

  • Hyperextension at the MCP joints and flexion at the IP joints of the ring and little fingers (4th and 5th digits)
  • Unopposed action of the extensor digitorum causes hyperextension of the MCP joints (Option A)
  • Unopposed flexion by flexor digitorum profundus & superficialis causes flexion of PIP & DIP joints
  • Thumb, index, and middle fingers appear relatively unaffected

Muscles paralysed:

  • Lumbricals of the 4th and 5th digits (normally flex MCP and extend IP joints)
  • Interossei muscles (palmar and dorsal)
